FacilityName: Travis County MUD #4 Water Treatment Plant

_prev_prog_3.Description: The release/accident/exposure prevention plan contains the following primary components: (a) off-site classroom and on-site on-the-job supervised training of all workers authorized to work on the chlorine system; (b) safe operating and maintenance procedures;  vacuum operated chlorine transfer system which automatically stops the release of chlorine from the storage cylinder if the vacuum is broken; (d) a chlorine gas detection and alarm system with remote alarms; (e) a trained leak repair response team; and (f) daily inspections of all systems and a routine preventive maintenance program.

_emerg_resp.CoordinatingAgencyName: Travis Co. Office of Emergency Mgm

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Travis County Municipal Utility District #4 Water Treatment Plant
EPA Risk Management Plan - Executive Summary
June 2004



1.0  Owner/Operator
    
This site is owned by Travis County Municipal Utility District No. 4 (MUD) and operated by ECO Resources, Inc. The RMP incorporates the release prevention, emergency response, and training provisions of both the owner and operator, since these two entities coordinate implementation of on-site procedures to ensure that employees are properly prepared to prevent and respond to emergencies.

2.0  Stationary Source Description

This source is a 3 million gallon per day municipal utility district water treatment (water supply) plant that provides potable water for the Barton Creek Subdivision.  One of the components of the treatment plant is disinfection of the water by chlorination.  This site is located in an area where the terrain consists of relatively steep hills.

3.0  Regulated Substances

The only regulated substance present at this facility is chlorine gas, which is delivered in one ton cylinders.

4.0  Release Scenarios 
 
Methodology given in the RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance was used to determine worst and alternative case release scenarios.  The model RMP*Comp Version 1.07 was used with default weather conditions for worst case and neutral conditions.

5.0  Accidental Release Administrative Controls and Mitigative Measures

Travis County MUD #4 is subject to the requirements of OSHA 1910.38 and 1910.120, and this site qualifies as a Program 3 Risk Management Plan submittal.  It is the policy of the MUD and ECO Resources, Inc. to fully comply with OSHA and Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) regulations regarding the storage and use of hazardous materials.

No engineered passive controls are in place for a chlorine release from this site.  Active controls consist of chlorine gas monitors near the chlorine gas system that provide direct chlorine readings at the site and sound alarms at the ECO Resources

, Inc. building.  ECO Resources, Inc. has emergency equipment and a leak repair kit.  A self-contained breathing apparatus is kept at the facility for use by personnel responding to a leak.  There are emergency procedures in place for stopping leaks and for notification of local authorities and emergency response teams. 

6.0  Five-year Accident History

There have been no accidents or releases at this site resulting in injuries or property damage.

7.0  Emergency Response Program

Upon discovery of a leak by an employee or local resident report or via the chlorine gas monitor/alarm system, ECO Resources, Inc. notifies the local chlorine response team and the facility operator.  On-site response time is 30 minutes or less.  If the response team determines that 10 pounds of chlorine have been released, or if there is a potential health or off-site health threat, the proper authorities are notified immediately.  The response team will also take immediate steps to shutdown the system and stop/repair the source of the release.

8.0  Changes to Improve Safety

No changes to improve the safety of this site are currently pending or being implemented.  There are no recommended changes at this time.
